moves.3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 Be7: Black chooses a slow, but solid setup...
moves.6. Bd3 O-O 7. O-O c5: an unusual outbreak in the center: Black is already in search for more space...
moves.8. Nf3 Bg4 9. h3 Bh5: to avoid further complications, better Bxf3...
moves.10. Bg5 Nbd7 11. Kh2 h6 12. Bxf6 Nxf6 13: after Bg6, Nh4, Bh7, Nf5, Whites' position unfolds really nicely: Black has to come up with something, but his solution might be a bit drastic...
Black has two pawns for the sacrificed light piece: but his Kings' wing is left rather drafty...
moves.19. Rg1: of course, the threat is Bxh5...
moves.19... Kh7 20. Nd5: I thought it was too early for Bxh5, Qf6! (gxh5?, Qxh5+, ends all), and the pressure on f2 becomes nasty; also worth considering was Qd5, but I wanted to keep all options for the Queen open...
moves.20... Bg5 21. Qd3: again creating a pin enforcing Bxh5, in case of a possibility for e4-e5...
moves.21... Qd7+ 22. Kg2: looklng for clues: another option was Kh2, Qd8, and we reach nothing; we decide to move the King out of the way, and utilize the h-file...
moves.26. Qd4: little by little, White is closing in on Black...
moves.26... f6: maybe best: create a stronghold for the King, after Kg7...
moves.27. Rag1: practically forcing f6-f5, to release the cramped Bg5 and the pressure on square f6: but then might follow e5, bringing up all kinds of other threats...
moves.27... Rae8: extra coverage for square e5, but this might be asking too much from Blacks' position...
moves.28... fxg5: Kxg5 might turn out even worse, after Qe3 and mate...
moves.29. Nf6: the culmination of Whites' attack: not only winning the material balance, but also obtaining a winning position...
moves.29... Qe6: maybe the best, but after Nxe8, Rxe8, Kd2, Black has nothing left: so he resigned on the spot...
